After discrete, you can smoothly segue into continuous distributions.

The lines are smoother, but the spirit is the same. The area under the curve - sum of all event's probability - is one. https://t.co/DxWu4IgqnO

The above üëÜgraph is a probability mass function - the probability of a four discrete events.

Sometimes you'll want to see a cumulative distribution instead üëá This allows you to quickly see the probability of 2 or more discrete events.

In both cases, they add up to 1.0. https://t.co/BK1JVavUFb

Discrete events are a fine place to start for understanding probability distributions. You can often count the number of discrete events in your situation üßÆüñêÔ∏è.

For example, in a medical diagnostic situation, there are four discrete outcomes: https://t.co/JB3HlgMuAD

‚úçÔ∏èProbability Distributions with Python: Discrete & Continuous on @hashnode
